ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Lan Tang  Tang, Lan
Instructor: Lan Tang  Didn't have much interaction but was helpful with comments on reports.
Instructor: Lan Tang  Very helpful with homework comments
Instructor: Lan Tang  NA
Instructor: Lan Tang  Never heard from or interacted with this person
Instructor: Lan Tang  Lan Tang
Instructor: Lan Tang  Lan most often. Though I hear Thomas was great!
Instructor: Lan Tang  Lan Tang
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  Thomas Lyttelton
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  I never interacted with either TA so cannot answer these questions
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  Thomas Lyttelton
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  NA
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  Never heard from or interacted with this person
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  I really liked Tom, he was very nice and helpful.
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  Thomas was very helpful in office hours and provided great feedback on homework

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Lan Tang  The teaching was very clear and helpful. The TA is very easy to reach and willing to answer all questions.
Instructor: Lan Tang  Could have mentioned were and how many point were lost.
Instructor: Lan Tang  Strength: good comments on the homework assignments.
Instructor: Lan Tang  Lan is the most harsh grader I have ever encountered in my academic career.
Instructor: Lan Tang  Accessible, helpful, broking things down well--could possibly give other sources of info when unable to answer questions.

Instructor: Lan Tang  I typically went to most of Lan's sessions and found her extremely helpful. I learned a lot in the course and a significant amount of it was from working with Lan. One of the best TFs I have had a chance to interact with.
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  Gave good comments on homework.
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  Very helpful, very responsive to emails, useful comments on assignments.
Instructor: Thomas Ivan Lyttelton  I only went to get his help once, but he was great, no complaints.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Best prof at Yale in my experience.
Great stuff!

I appreciated that the course was geared towards completing a project of our own without any assignments that felt like busy work. I also appreciated that using different software packages was welcomed, this helped introduce me to several packages, which is very useful.
Question 15: Some more focus on developing coding skills for beginners could be helpful.

JR is an amazing professor... no one else could get students so excited about statistics. He made class so fun and engaging that I genuinely wanted to show up, even though he also videotaped all his lectures, which was also so valuable in learning the material. He was also readily available and responsive. In terms of the content, I think Jonathan did a good job balancing theory with applications. We learned the basic math/theory behind the statistical tools we were using, but didn't go into unnecessary depth.
Professor Scherer was great to work with.

Jonathan was a great instructor. He was super helpful with the class when we needed help and her replied very fast on emails and making appointments were very easy. He was even helpful with general statistics questions that was not even related to this class. Great statistics professor! I was little worried before taking this class because it has been awhile since my last stats. class in undergrad but Jonathan was super helpful so I was able to catch up really fast. Would definitely take his classes again.

I suggest review and improving the slides. There were almost a thousand slides, with no apparent order and some duplicated content. There was no consistent flow, as could be seen from jumping around back and forth frequently in class. I would like to see step by step to do each analysis. 1) do this test 2) do this test 3) interpret this value 4) etc.

JDRS is a master lecturer, entertaining and erudite. But the material is extremely complex, and requires both conceptual underpinnings and software capabilities I struggled with--and I wish there were more support for this. I never saw, met, or heard from any of the TAs; I'm not even sure they were actually involved in the class at all. JDRS is very smart and, when you can pin him down, helpful, but it was hard to schedule my work schedule around his and so many students needed his step-by-step help; I wish there were more hands-on guidance from the Statlab for many of these concepts and techniques. Also, at the end of the course, JDRS taught Amos for SEM, and we were really excited to use it--only to find that not a single computer at Yale had Amos installed, and we had to go through a whole rigmarole to get that accomplished, which wasted precious time at the end of the semester. Frustrating that basic stuff like that wouldn't have just been communicated earlier.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The prof for this course, JRS, is amazing -- creative, energetic, and great at explaining things. The timing for this class (right after lunch on Tuesdays/Thursdays) wasn't optimal, but he kept us awake with stories and inside jokes. He was also very available for office hours and incredibly patient if you went to him with questions.
Clear, entertaining lectures that broke down difficult concepts with ease.

Doing homework on our own datasets was an excellent call - especially for the final project, it was a lot more engaging and motivating to work on something where I was genuinely interested in the answer (and follow-up work might be publishable).

The flexibility of the course, allowing students to watch lecture videos if they had another class with a conflicting time. I was able to take this course and fit it into my own schedule without having a conflict detract from my learning.
The professor is very friendly and approachable. The topics discussed are very applicable to empirical analysis.

The class itself ended up being as much work as you put in. If you put in the bare minimum (which was a decent amount of work but not overwhelming), the coursework/problem sets were helpful enough that you still got to learn all the fundamentals of the course. If you wanted to put in more effort, the problem sets enabled you to do so, and the prof was there to help too. The fact that you could use your own datasets helped student really engage with- and feel accountable to- the material in a way that wouldn't be possible with more traditional problem sets. I also really liked that the course was inclusive of so many disciplines, as it allowed us to experience creative and diverse applications of statistical tools, which is valuable in research.
Professor Jonathan was great to work with. Really well set up class.
Great course. I have learned so much and I will definitely use what I have learned from this class to my research.

The course was very well organized and this helped in understanding how each multivariate approach could be applied in different situations. The flexibility in working with a data set of choice helped frame the key concepts of this course in a way we could easily relate to. The ability of the tools used to help visualize output thorough different techniques taught in class was one of the best aspects of this class. Visualizing complex interactions between variables, spatially as well made this course really interesting. The software examples were also handy in helping with the coding process.
Going through the homework assignments was very helpful in really getting to undersatnd the concepts in this course.
Interesting class, Jonathan is a great professor and engaging. The techniques will give you a broad sense of multivariate stats but it will require you to engage if you want to get deeper.
Concrete practice using multivariate techniques, which are explained dynamically and with humor by a great professor.
Professor is great! Makes stats accessible and engaging.
I really enjoy Jonathan's work to make the class interesting and fun.

I really like that this course allows students to work with their own data to learn and implement the multivariate techniques. I also appreciate that students are free to work on their own or in groups, as they choose. It is also very nice that Jonathan allows us to work in any of the statistical programs we choose. His knowledge of each is an awesome asset to the course and it makes the material so much more relevant and useful to a broad audience!
Instructor enthusiasm
Showed how to make stats applicable to real data.

the project-based homeworks are an excellent way to learn to work with multivariate statistics in a practical and applied manner. Prof. Reuning-Scherer is also extremely flexible and responsive to students.

The content of this course was explained incredibly well. The instructor is engaging and very knowledgable. The course notes are thorough and easy to follow. The recorded class videos were also helpful. Instructor was available for office hours, as were TFs.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Timing -- 1pm (right after lunch) on Tuesdays/Thursdays is a tough time to keep people awake in a dark room. Also, the availability of the video was amazing for those of us who had to travel, but didn't inspire people to come to class much... that's not really an area for improvement, just a general comment.
Nothing.

I found that if I zoned out briefly, or my mind was slightly too slow recalling how (say) an eigenvalue was calculated, I could miss a lot of things - you'd say something that seemed important, but I'd feel like my brain was missing a lot of the reasons *why* it was important. ("Wait, why is it significant that this technique does not require the variables to be correlated?" etc.) I think this is common to any topic like this, though, so there might not be much you can do to avoid it. More reminders of previously-covered concepts might not hurt. It was sometimes possible to complete aspects of the assignments without feeling like I fully understood the underlying concepts. Overall, though, they were pretty well-designed.
There were not that many TAs, so maybe having a better system of finding qualified TAs would help
Overall a good course. I enjoyed being a part of it.
Having taken an introductory stats class a long time ago, I could have used a little more reviewing prior to some of the stats tools, e.g. MANOVA.
there can be more sessions for softwares.
The course can be little too fast...

The course could benefit from being talk in a more intimate and interactive setting where students can perhaps even perform exercises relevant to the day's lecture in class. I think the course could also benefit from more than one software 'bootcamp.' Lastly, given the enormous amount of technical skills from this class, the lecture could benefit from a professional data skills recitation session.
Maybe the pace of the class could use some improvement. Sometimes the theoretical explanation, while important seem disconnected from the assignments and the practical exercises.

My major complaint is this: We're encouraged to work in groups and submit homework assignments jointly - but group members who don't submit the assignments are then unable to see any TF feedback when the assignment is returned. There must be a better way to submit/return assignments!

This is both a positive and a negative: I was able to complete the course with an extremely limited understanding of the math behind the techniques. This was certainly my own fault for not taking more time to understand the concepts. BUT it is something that I had focused more on.
Software management and training with students; TA involvement
Sometimes I wish the instructor better connected the minutiae he's discussing the broader picture of the technique he's addressing.
It would be nice if the homeworks were a bit more challenging, sometimes I felt if i had any problems i could look at the examples and piece together an answer without understanding it.

Many students do not attend class in person. It would be great to have the course held in a smaller classroom so those present could have more meaningful discussions and be more inclined to ask questions. Perhaps a clear online option to determine how many students will actually be in class and plan accordingly?
Clarity of connection, and when to use each analysis.

For me, going through, some times I got lost in the details of the methods and needed to take a step back to remember the goal. At the beginning of the course was a decision tree for when you would use different methods; I think it would be useful to refer to that at the start of each new topic to see where it fits in.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA
Great work in the discussion sections. Super helpful!
Great course. Loved the part with videos. Really helped go over basics.
Relatively useful.
it was very effective
Office hours were great.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This was a useful complement to our intro R and intro stats analysis classes last semester -- a very helpful way to keep practicing R and STATA skills.
Critical training in advanced statistical methods and coding in R.
Lots of useful general tools for my work here, I feel a lot more equipped to understand the appropriate methodologies when people use statistical methods in my field.
A useful overview to more advanced statistical techniques
I am an Economics student so taking this course was helpful as the methods I learnt could be applied to my data analysis work for my final research paper.

I study epidemiology, and more specifically disease ecology, which requires the use of diverse mathematical/statistical tools. This class helped me learn multivariate techniques that could be applied to my research.
Was very useful for my research. I used states to analyze mt research data which worked perfectly.
This course is exactly what I needed. I think everyone in FES should take this class. It is super helpful.

This course is useful in disciplines that interface with the social sciences. I am focusing on climate and energy at F&ES but I also have academic interests in understanding the human aspects of both. AS such, understanding how to handle data sets with multiple variables and to make sensible inferences from these data set is a useful skills to have professionally.
Really important for anyone doing more than OLS and univariate states (no one does univariate stats anymore)
As a water professional statistics is important in analysis field data.

This course addressed statistical analytical methods that I'll need for any type of sophisticated research/manuscript I design/produce. It also helps me understand the methods employed by my colleagues when I'm reading scientific literature. I think this course is incredibly relevant to my program.
This course is a great fit for my overall program because I am studying ecology. The techniques have allowed me to think about my research questions in totally different (and better!) ways.
As a PhD student in Environmental Engineering, I'm bound to be analyzing sets of data. This course illuminated a variety of options for doing so that I was less familiar with.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To keep practicing stats analysis skills in different softwares and get to learn more complicated ways of approaching groups of variables.
Build up my R toolbox.
Highly relevant to my work.
To become familiar with more statistical techniques.
learn some technical skills
I wanted to improve my data analysis skills.
Advice from other students in my department; necessity to gain better statistical tools/knowledge; wanted to take a class with JR
Because I wanted to learn R and it helped with my research
I needed to do statistical analysis for my research.

I took this course because my final project from Statistics 1 was a topic I am passionate about and concepts taught in this class were useful in addressing some of the un-answered questions I had from the statistics 1 final project.
For my master's research it is important that I know how to use multivariate statistics to analyze my data.
it would build skills that i can use in other areas
See question 20. Also, I think the professor is great.
This course is essential to my course of study as an ecologist.
To be able to analyze data with a more interesting set of tools
To improve my analytical/quantitative skills.
I wanted to learn multivariate concepts and techniques for my research and career.
I merely audited.
Wanted to understand how to interact with big data.
I will need to use multivariate statistics for analyzing data for research.

I had taken statistics courses before, but found that when actually using the tools I lacked some knowledge, so this was an opportunity to improve. I also wanted to learn R, which I now have a basic handle on. Also, I needed to take three science/engineering/math courses for my Environmental Engineering PhD requirement.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, definitely
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes
Yes
Yes
coding and statistical analysis
Yes, to a certain extent. I expected a little more help with learning how to code.
The slides and resources on them are immensely helpful. I can't think of a better way to learn the material than this course design.
Yes; the statistical methods were laid out in the first class, and the class stuck pretty directly to the syllabus.
Yes very useful.
Yes, I learned what I wanted to learn.
Yes and I look forward to improving my skills in writing code independently using tools such as R and STATA.
Yes, I understand most of the overarching concepts, though I do not feel like I have a solid grasp on the implementation of all of them.
Yes!,
Yes, i learned what i would have liked to learn
Yes
Exceeded expectations.

Just about; I wish I felt stronger about, e.g., R, although I feel decent about SPSS now. I also think this course might have been more valuable to take next spring, after my data had been collected during this summer's research.
Yes
Very much so!
Somewhat. Showed how much is needed in order to understand statistics fully.
Mostly, yes. I was hoping for a refresher on basic multiple variable regression at the beginning, though.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It helped my learned process to discuss any of my own uncertainties with my group members.
very helpful to learn
We could all play to our strengths. Some people were better at coding, others were better at applying the concepts and interpreting results.

One big advantage was that all group members had strengths in different softwares, so together we had at least one group member able to use all softwares recommended in the class. This gave us the flexibility to use the most appropriate/helpful software for each analysis, and gave us exposure to new softwares that we hadn't all used before. Additionally, working in a group allowed us to discuss the material in great depth and problem-shoot/solve material that weren't comfortable with. I thought this class lent itself very well to a group format, and I don't think I would have learned as much had I tried to do the HWs on my own. Also, it made stats more fun, and decreased the work load, which was nice.
Helped to divide work equally and share ideas.
thumbs up.
No disadvantages... Jonathan let you choose your own group members and I loved working with all my group members.

Advantages - Some group members were experiences in handling spatial statistical data and this helped in approaching the problem sets. Disadvantages - Scheduling and time constraint challenges. Also, there was great synergistic output which was the result of deliberate efforts to also get some team members to contribute more.

Working in a group was essential for me in this course. As I worked my way through difficult concepts it was very helpful to be able to talk through what I was doing with someone else, and learn together. Especially when working with R it was helpful to have someone in my group who had some experience so that I wasn't just struggling to make the program work and I could focus more on the statistical concepts.
Better balance of workload.
-Better understanding of material. -Work got done faster
Even if you are someone who doesn't typically enjoy/seek out group work, I highly recommend it for this course. Your group will become a much-needed support network as the semester progresses.

Talking through the theory and methods is helpful, and my group members offered different perspectives and explanations that helped me learn the material. On the other hand, I prefer to work independently. I think there is value to working though every step of a problem set and directing every output of a stats software package. Personally, when these steps are shared and divided up, I don't think I learn them as well.
It really helped me feel less lost, and we could teach each other the concepts we learned.
I really love that I had the option to either work in a small group or independently. I learn much better on my own and appreciated the opportunity to do so.
Great. They were like additional TAs.
Groups were useful ways to work through code and see how others would write it. It also was very helpful as a way to learn how to do something.
Advantages: Group problem solving, learning code from each other, practicing group dynamics Disadvantages: Scheduling conflicts

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You can put as much effort into this class as you want, and you can also put very little effort into it and do fine. It's worth it to do the former, though -- you'll learn a lot.
Stay on top of the homework and take advantage of the ample office hours available.

If you didn't understand some concept from lecture, it's worthwhile going back and reviewing it (with any of the many provided resources!) before the next lecture - the understanding debt can pile up.
This was a pretty comfortable and not-scary environment in which to learn statistics - I'm not a math person and felt that I learned a lot and the work was manageable.
audit or taking it for credit is worthy it!
Brush up on coding skills. Great opportunity to learn more about data analysis.

The class is MUCH more valuable if you come in with your own dataset and study questions/hypotheses. My group didn't have our own dataset until the final project, but I was friends with people who had collected and were using their own data, and I think they got much more out of the course. In the final project, I found that my group was more committed to learning/applying the course's statistical methods when we had our own data. More generally, take this course! It's fun and helpful in orienting yourself (and your research) in multidimensional space!
Just take it. Professor Scherer is simply the best.
just do it.
Take this course. You will gain a lot...

While the course can be time consuming and challenging at times, the multivariate data skills learnt are worthwhile for anyone interested in social science and big environmental data research. Also, anyone interested in honing skills in R, SPSS and STATA should consider enrolling in this course.
Make sure you keep up with the lectures, and leave plenty of time to do the homework, especially if you are unfamiliar with the program that you are using for the homework assignments.
Commit and get your own dataset to work on, so you can take advantage of the class.
Take it. Jonathan is an excellent professor.
It is a good skill course. Take it if you want to learn how to use different statistical softwares
Work in a group. Keep up with the material from the beginning and your final project will come together quite smoothly.
Have data that's important to you and that you're interested in analyzing. If you don't have your own data, start looking as early as possible and ask for help/loaner data.
Take it!

I recommend you come in with a really solid dataset that you can use for the whole semester, that you know the ins and outs of, that has lots of quantitative variables, no missing data, and a very high number of observations. Also, consider ways of taking notes that don't distract you or make you too crazy from trying to keep up with JDRS's adventures in multi-dimensional space.
Recommend taking it.

You will learn the most from this class if you read about the techniques, attend class and/or watch the videos (I often re-visit videos while doing homework), and run through the examples that Jonathan provides at home.

Come with a clear set of research questions and a healthy set of expectations that not all of them (indeed, even any of them) can be met. It helps to have data that you care about, though. Can use this information in other aspects of your work.
Use R.... and if possible, try to take a basic R class beforehand.
Pick a group that you like working with and has similar schedules, because you will be spending a lot of time together! Choose a dataset from the start instead of working with provided data.
